description: From Middle English fever, fevere, from Old English fefer, fefor (“fever”), from Latin febris (“a fever”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰegʷʰ- (“to burn”). Replaced native Old English hriþ (“fever”). Compare also Saterland Frisian Fiewer, German Fieber, Danish feber, Swedish feber.

entries.meaning: A higher than normal body temperature of a person (or, generally, a mammal), usually caused by disease.
examples: "I have a fever. I think I've the flu."

entries.meaning: (usually in combination with one or more preceding words) Any of various diseases.
A state of excitement or anxiety.

verbs.description: fever (third-person singular simple present fevers, present participle fevering, simple past and past participle fevered)

entries.meaning: To put into a fever; to affect with fever.
